questions.text: An 18-month-old child is brought to OPD with complaints of blood in his urine. Examination reveals a non-tender mass in the left flank that does not cross the midline. Blood pressure is also found to be elevated. Imaging reveals a left renal tumor and surgical resection is planned. The gross appearance of the mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing a well-circumscribed tumor with multiple necrotic, hemorrhagic, and cystic changes in the upper pole of the kidney are suggestive of a nephroblastoma or Wilms' tumor. 

It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (2-5 years of age). Around 10% of cases are associated with genetic syndromes and gonadal dysgenesis may be seen. 

Clinical manifestations of Wilms' tumor include:

  • Large abdominal mass - usually unilateral and does not cross the midline
  • Abdominal pain
  • Hematuria
  • Hypertension
  • Intestinal obstruction (in some cases) 

Nephrogenic rests are the precursor lesions of Wilms' tumor and suggest an increased risk of developing a contralateral Wilms' tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Wilms tumor?

choices.text: It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
It is associated with MIC-2 gene expression
It is associated with the  deletion of chromosome 11p13
The most common presentation is hematuria

questions.solution:
Wilms' tumor is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13.

It is an autosomal-dominant disorder. The most common clinical presentation is an abdominal mass.

Note: MIC-2 gene expression is seen in neuroblastoma.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: In patients with  Wilms tumors, which of the following microscopic features are indicative of resistance to chemotherapy?
questions.solution:
In Wilms' tumor, the presence of anaplasia is indicative of resistance to chemotherapy. 

This correlates with the presence of TP53 mutations and, hence, is associated with a poor prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in Wilms' tumor?
questions.solution:
Anaplastic histology is the most important prognostic factor in Wilms' tumor.

It is seen in about 5% of cases and is characterized by the presence of cells with large, hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei, and abnormal mitoses. It is associated with TP53 mutations and resistance to chemotherapy.

Anaplasia is uncommon in children < 2 years. Hence, tumors presenting at an young age have a significantly better prognosis than those presenting in older children.

Prognostic factors in Wilms' tumor include:

  Favorable prognosis Adverse prognosis
Histologic type Classic triphasic component Anaplastic histology
Tumor stage Low High
Molecular alterations  ----

11q deletion

16q deletion

Gain of chromosome 1q
Age of onset <2 years >2 years

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Wilms tumor?
questions.solution:
Bilateral polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilms tumor.

Wilms' tumor can be associated with:

  • Aniridia - WAGR syndrome
  • Gonadal dysgenesis - Denys–Drash syndrome
  • Hemihypertrophy and omphalocele - Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is being evaluated for a history of recurrent seizures and abdominal discomfort. Examination reveals the following nail findings. Which of the following should she be screened for?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing periungual fibromas are strongly suggestive of tuberous sclerosis. This condition is associated with renal angiomyolipomas (present in 25–50% of cases).

Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder that has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

The clinical features of tuberous sclerosis include:

  • Skin lesions -
    • Hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules 
    • Periungual fibromas or Koenen tumors (small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails or toenails)
    • Shagreen patch- roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, primarily in the lumbosacral region
    • Facial angiofibromas
    • Confetti skin lesions 
  • Neurological features -
    • Epilepsy and intellectual disability (due to cortical tubers)
    • Autism spectrum disorder
    • Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas
  • Other tumors -
    • Cardiac rhabdomyoma
    • Renal angiomyolipomas, renal cysts
    • Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis

Angiomyolipoma is a benign renal neoplasm (hamartoma) originating from perivascular epithelioid cells (PEComa). It consists of vessels, smooth muscle, and fat in variable proportions. They are highly susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage.

The histological image of renal angiomyolipoma is given below:

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes

Syndrome Mutation in 
Clinical manifestations
von Hippel–Lindau VHL gene (3p 25-26)
  • Clear cell RCC, renal cysts
  • Retinal angiomas (benign)
  • CNS hemangioblastomas (benign)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • Cystadenoma
  • Endolymphatic sac tumors
Hereditary papillary RCC C-met proto-oncogene (7q31)
  • Multiple & bilateral type1 papillary RCC
Tuberous sclerosis  TSC1 (9q34) TSC2 (16p13)
  • Clear cell RCC
  • Multiple renal angiomyolipomas
  • Polycystic kidney disease
  • Cutaneous angiofibroma
  • Periungual fibroma
  • Shagreen patch
  • Ashleaf macules
  • Cardiac Rhabdomyoma
  • Subependymal nodules
  • Cortical tubers in CNS
  • Pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis
Birt–Hogg–Dube  BHD gene: Folliculin (17p11)
  • Multiple chromophobe RCC
  • Hybrid oncocytic tumor 
  • Oncocytomas                   
  • Clear-cell RCC          
  • Papillary RCC                 
  • Facial fibrofoliculomas   
  • Lung cysts               
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax
Hereditary leiomyomatosis Fumarate hydratase (1q42-43)
  • Type 2 papillary RCC   
  • Collecting-duct RCC 
  • Leiomyomas of skin or uterus
  • Uterine leiomyosarcomas
Cowden syndrome PTEN (10q23) 
  • Benign and malignant breast tumors 
  • Epithelial thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary RCC or other histological subtypes
 

Note: RCC with syndromic associations tends to be bilateral. They also occur early in life.

VHL: von Hippel–Lindau

RCC: Renal cell carcinoma

PTEN: phosphatase and tensin homolog gene

BHD: Birt Hogg Dube

TSC: Tuberous sclerosis complex

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient is being evaluated for chronic abdominal discomfort. CECT of the abdomen and pelvis shows a heterogeneously enhancing renal mass with a central stellate scar. On resection, the tumor appears mahogany brown. What is the site of origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is suggestive of renal oncocytoma. It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. 

It is a benign epithelial neoplasm. Grossly, these tumors appear tan or mahogany brown and relatively homogeneous. They are usually well encapsulated with a central scar in one-third of cases.

Microscopically, they are composed of large eosinophilic cells having small, round, benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. Ultrastructurally, these eosinophilic cells have numerous mitochondria.

The gross and histological appearances of renal oncocytoma are shown in the images given below:

Oncocytes refer to epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (due to the accumulation of mitochondria). They can arise in various tissues and are referred to as: 

  • Hurthle cells/Ashkenazy cells in the thyroid gland
  • Oxyphilic cells in the parotid gland
  • Apocrine metaplasia in the breast

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor?
questions.solution:
The most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor is the size of the tumor.

The papillary type of renal tumors includes: 

  • Renal papillary adenoma (≤ 1.5 cm) 
  • Papillary type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) - > 1.5 cm

Small renal papillary growths are fairly common and incidentally found. Ruling out of malignancy is one of the processes carried out during the evaluation of donor transplant kidneys.

Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the second most common type of renal cell carcinoma and it arises from proximal tubules. It can be multifocal or bilateral. It is typically hemorrhagic and cystic, especially when large.

It is often a circumscribed tumor composed of papillae formed by delicate fibrovascular cores that often contain foamy macrophages and Psammoma bodies.

It has two histological types:

  • Type 1 papillary RCC - single layer of cells on the basement membrane and low-grade nuclear features
  • Type 2 papillary RCC - pseudostratification of cells and usually has high-grade nuclear features

questions.text: The following image shows a nephrectomy specimen of a patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. What is the likely histopathological finding in this tumor?

choices.text: Small cells with high N/C ratio

questions.solution:
The given image shows a bright yellow variegated mass distorting the renal outline at the lower pole. This is suggestive of the clear cell type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The yellow color is due to prominent lipid accumulation.

Gross findings of various types of renal tumors:

 

Clear-cell RCC

 Papillary RCC Chromophobe RCC Oncocytoma Angiomyolipoma
Site of origin Proximal tubular epithelium

Proximal tubule

Intercalated cells of collecting ducts

Intercalated cells of collecting ducts

Perivascular epithelioid cells (PEComa)
Number Solitary, globular, unilateral

Multifocal and bilateral

 Solitary, unilateral Usually solitary Mostly solitary, can be multifocal
Color

Golden yellow, due to the high lipid content of their cells

 Grey tan to dark brown, depending on the degree of intratumoral hemorrhage

Light tan to brown

 Mahogany brown

Yellow to pinkish-tan, depending on the relative proportions of the various components
Capsule

Pseudocapsule+

 Pseudocapsule+ Circumscribed but unencapsulated Well encapsulated Circumscribed but unencapsulated
Appearance  Variegated with cysts, necrosis, hemorrhagic foci Variegated, friable Homogenous Homogenous Variable

questions.text: The nephrectomy specimen of a tumor of a 40-year-old man shows the following histological presentation. Which of the following familial cancer syndromes is this condition associated with?

choices.text: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image shows eosinophilic cells with prominent cell membranes and perinuclear halo, which is suggestive of chromophobe cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It is associated with Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome.

Other familial cancer syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them are:

  • Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome - papillary RCC
    • Large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large nuclei, and prominent inclusion-like eosinophilic nucleoli.
  • Tuberous sclerosis - clear-cell RCC
  • Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (VHL) - clear-cell RCC

The image given below shows the histology of chromophobe cell RCC.

questions.text: Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma is matched incorrectly with its respective cytogenetic patterns?

choices.text: Hereditary papillary RCC - loss of Y
Sporadic papillary RCC - loss of Y

questions.solution:
Loss of Y chromosome is a feature of sporadic papillary carcinoma, not hereditary papillary RCC.

Various types of renal carcinoma and their cytogenetic abnormalities are given below:

  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma -
    • Sporadic type - trisomies 7 and 17, loss of Y chromosome
    • Familial type - trisomy 7 (mapped to MET gene)
  • Clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma (whether familial, sporadic, or associated with VHL syndrome)
    • Loss of sequences on the short arm of chromosome 3, which harbors the VHL gene

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common histological subtype of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Clear-cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common histological subtype of renal cell carcinoma, accounting for 70% to 80% of renal cell cancers. 

It is most likely to arise from the proximal tubular epithelium as solitary lesions. It has a characteristic tendency to invade the renal vein. The histological features are:

  • Rounded or polygonal tumor cells
  • Abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids 
  • Arranged in a solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular pattern

 The histological appearance of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma is shown in the image given below:

Note: The Furhman nuclear grading system was previously used for histological grading of RCC (except chromophobe RCC). It is now replaced by the WHO/International Society of Urologic Pathology (ISUP) grading system.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors does not have papillary architecture on histopathology?
questions.solution:
Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-defi­cient renal cell carcinoma does not show papillary architecture. It is associated with a bubbly appearance of histopathology.

It is a malignant epithelial tumor associated with germline mutations in the SDH gene. It is composed of vacuolat­ed, eosinophilic-clear cells arranged in a solid, nested, or tubular pattern. The presence of the vacuoles imparts the characteristic bubbly appearance, as shown below.

Renal cell carcinoma subtypes with papillary architecture in histology:

  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Hereditary leiomyomatosis renal cell carcinoma
  • Xp11 translocation renal cell carcinoma
  • Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma shows large cells having a plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo on histological examination?
questions.solution:
Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma shows large cells having plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo. 

They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.

Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma can differentiated from oncocytoma and clear cell RCC as follows:

  • Oncocytoma does not show perinuclear halo whereas chromophobe RCC shows perinuclear halo
  •  CK7 is diffusely positive in chromophobe RCC but it is negative in clear-cell RCC.

Chromophobe RCC cannot be histologically graded because of its innate nuclear atypia.

 The histological image of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is given below: 

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A patient with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is found to have a renal tumor and malignancy is suspected. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the renal tumor associated with this condition?

choices.text: It constitutes 5% of all renal tumors
Cytogenetic testing of the tumor shows multiple chromosomal losses
It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct

questions.solution:
The renal tumor commonly associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It has an excellent prognosis.

It constitutes 5% of all renal carcinomas. It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct. Cytogenetic testing of the tumor shows multiple chromosomal losses and extreme hypodiploidy.

The histological image of chromophobe RCC is given below:

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors characteristically shows a  hobnail pattern on microscopy?
questions.solution:
Collecting duct carcinoma or Bellini duct carcinoma shows a characteristic hobnail pattern and prominent desmoplastic stroma on microscopy.

The hobnail pattern refers to the bulbous nuclear projections of epithelial cells that protrude into the lumen as little bumps. It is associated with tubular, tubulopapillary, or tubulo­cystic pattern.

Collecting duct carcinoma arises from the princi­pal cells of the renal collecting ducts of Bellini. The majority of these tumors are associated with poor out­come, due to their highly aggressive clin­ical course.

The histological section showing collecting duct carcinoma with the characteristic hobnail pattern is given below:

Note: The hobnail pattern is also seen in clear cell carcinoma of the ovary.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: Individuals with the sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
Individuals with the sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing medullary renal cell carcinoma.

It is a rare, highly aggressive neoplasm and is morphologically similar to collecting duct carcinoma.

The hypoxic microenvironment in the renal medulla created by hyper­osmolarity, low pH, and stasis enhances red blood sickling and ische­mic damage. This leads to chronic regenera­tive proliferation of medullary epithelium and activation of hypoxia-induced signaling pathways, which in turn promote neoplastic change. 

The histological section of renal medullary carcinoma showing prominent cytological atypia is shown below:

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A pathologist is studying the histopathological slide from a nephrectomy specimen from a patient with renal carcinoma. He observes neoplastic cells with clear cytoplasm and papillary architecture. Which of the following subtypes of renal carcinoma is this likely to be?
questions.solution:
Xp11 translocation carcinoma contains neoplastic cells with clear cytoplasm with a papillary architecture on histopathology. It is also associated with Psammoma bodies.

This condition is caused by translocations of the TFE3 gene located on Xp11.2, which results in overexpression of the TFE3 transcription factor. It often occurs in young patients and is associated with a poor prognosis.

The histological section of Xp11 translocation carcinoma is given below:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding renal cell carcinoma?

choices.text: It can invade the renal vein
It may arise from the proximal convoluted tubule

questions.solution:
Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is more common among males, with a male to female ratio of 2:1.

Renal cell carcinoma may arise from the proximal convoluted tubules (PCT). The classical clinical features of renal cell carcinoma are costovertebral pain, palpable mass, and painless hematuria. It characteristically invades the renal vein and has a high tendency for distant metastasis. 

Paraneoplastic manifestations of renal cell carcinoma include: 

  • Polycythemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypertension
  • Hepatic dysfunction
  • Feminization or masculinization
  • Cushing syndrome
  • Eosinophilia
  • Leukemoid reactions
  • Amyloidosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of metastasis of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common site of metastasis in renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the lung (more than 50%).

Common sites of metastasis of renal cell carcinoma in descending order are:

  • Lungs
  • Bones - osteolytic lesions
  • Regional lymph nodes
  • Liver
  • Adrenals
  • Brain 

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma has the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma has the worst prognosis of all renal cell carcinoma subtypes.

The renal cell carcinoma subtypes with poor prognosis in descending order are

  • Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma
  • Medullary renal cell carcinoma
  • Clear cell renal cell carcinoma

Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma has the best prognosis.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: Which of the following genes is not mutated in familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes?
questions.solution:
WT gene is mutated in Wilms' tumor, not renal cell carcinoma. 

The following gene mutations are associated with familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes:

  • C-met proto-oncogene
  • Fumarate hydratase gene
  • BHD gene
  • VHL gene
  • TSC1 gene
  • PTEN gene

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes

Syndrome Mutation in 
Clinical manifestations
von Hippel–Lindau VHL gene (3p 25-26)
  • Clear cell RCC, renal cysts
  • Retinal angiomas (benign)
  • CNS hemangioblastomas (benign)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • Cystadenoma
  • Endolymphatic sac tumors
Hereditary papillary RCC C-met proto-oncogene (7q31)
  • Multiple & bilateral type1 papillary RCC
Tuberous sclerosis  TSC1 (9q34) TSC2 (16p13)
  • Clear cell RCC
  • Multiple renal angiomyolipomas
  • Polycystic kidney disease
  • Cutaneous angiofibroma
  • Periungual fibroma
  • Shagreen patch
  • Ashleaf macules
  • Cardiac Rhabdomyoma
  • Subependymal nodules
  • Cortical tubers in CNS
  • Pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis
Birt–Hogg–Dube  BHD gene: Folliculin (17p11)
  • Multiple chromophobe RCC
  • Hybrid oncocytic tumor 
  • Oncocytomas                   
  • Clear-cell RCC          
  • Papillary RCC                 
  • Facial fibrofoliculomas   
  • Lung cysts               
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax
Hereditary leiomyomatosis Fumarate hydratase (1q42-43)
  • Type 2 papillary RCC   
  • Collecting-duct RCC 
  • Leiomyomas of skin or uterus
  • Uterine leiomyosarcomas
Cowden syndrome PTEN (10q23) 
  • Benign and malignant breast tumors 
  • Epithelial thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary RCC or other histological subtypes
 

Note: RCC with syndromic associations tends to be bilateral. They also occur early in life.

VHL: von Hippel–Lindau

RCC: Renal cell carcinoma

PTEN: phosphatase and tensin homolog gene

BHD: Birt Hogg Dube

TSC: Tuberous sclerosis complex

questions.text: Which of the following pairs correctly describes the immunohistochemical property of renal cell carcinoma in a cancer of unknown origin?
questions.solution:
Renal cell carcinoma is CK7 negative and CK20 negative.

The most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma is clear-cell renal cell carcinoma, which is CK7 negative. Therefore, in determining the origin of cancer of unknown primary, immunohistochemistry (IHC) expression of renal cell carcinoma will generally be CK7 negative and CK20 negative. Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma and papillary renal cell carcinoma are positive for CK7. 

Related Pearl: Role of CK7 and CK20 Markers in Tumors of Unknown Primary

Cytokeratin is an epithelial marker. A combination of CK7 and CK20 is used to identify the organ of origin.

CK7 CK20 Common Cancers

-

Lung,

Thyroid

 
- + Colorectal
- -
